content.description: Tricky moves right into hanging corner lead to steep face climbing above.
content.location: Bolted line just right of Solar Flare

content.description: Getting on to the ledge after the layback is a bit awkward and I think it is the crux.
content.location: Left of the route Red Dwarf.  Follow trail left from    The Griddle.  Continue left at the cairn another 50 feet.  It is the crack around the corner from the left angling crack on the steep red face. If you go right at the cairn it leads to the upper tiers Brown Dwarf and Heliosphere

content.description: Hard moves up short crack with good pro get you to another short section of crack.  From the ledge follow bolts left on to fun overhanging face.  Originally lead by Jim Scott but he stayed right and climbed easy rock to top with no pro after the cracks.  Much more fun to do with the bolts on the steep face.
content.protection: Cams to hand jam size.  Bolts
content.location: Starts ten 15 feet right of Red Dwarf

content.description: Crack to face.  The climbing is better than the climbs appearance.
content.protection: Bolts and a light rack of cams to 3 inches.
content.location: Right most route on the right side of the Heliosphere.  Walk up and over the small saddle to the right.

climbs.name: Tallest Man On Earth
climbs.fa: EFR,JSt,David Merin,Josie Becker,Eric Ruljancich,Christian Rodenbeck, Max

content.description: This is a variation finish to Hashbrowns.  A cool committing move with nice air lead to a big jug then a hard traverse and pumpy gear placements.  Stays on you even when it looks like it should be over.  Pro is good but a little shallow small and spooky.  A failure of the gear on the traverse could lead to a swing into a ramp.  Long slings on the last bolt and the first gear placements really help with the rope drag. We did this route after toproping it once, so although we didn't have the gear completely dialed we did have a clue and that helps.  This would be a proud onsight and I base the rating on that.  If it was a clip up I would probably call it an 11+.  Will change it if needed as more folks climb it. Rock is a little chossy in places but should clean up with some work and traffic. D. Merin did the lower half using sparse gear placements and 4 ft. runners to reduce drag and make the whole thing trad.
content.protection: If you just do the finish with trad gear you need Cams to yellow Camalot.  A purple Camalot and a yellow metolius can be had at the first jug.  A blue mastercam (fell on it once) in a shallow horizontal after traversing or you fill a handhold, then a purple master just above it in an angling crack are all that is between you and a collision with stone.  After that a yellow camalot then a blue mastercam, then a red camalot with a long sling, and maybe one or two greens will get you to the top.  If you skip the bolts on the first half you will need more gear to protect it.
content.location: Start up Hashbrowns and as you get to the bulge below the chimney clip the bolt below the bulge with a long sling then move up even with the lip of the bulge and climb right to a horizontal.  After getting bomber gear with a long sling, continue right four feet or so, place small cams then head up the face to crack eventually working right to another crack and the anchors

content.description: Fun Warm up, a bit harder than it looks.   Climb slab to steep section then up to bulge. Pull through bulge on jug to slabby finish.
content.location: Bolted slab left of Hard Boiled,

climbs.name: Sun Stoked
climbs.fa: JSt,EFR, Doug Cornick '16 (left Start EFR,JSt, DCk '16)

content.description: Two starts to this route. the left is 11+ the right is the 5.11. Hard start with a couple of more steep hard sections. Better than you think it will be and the middle crux is a head scratcher.
content.location: Right of Sun Dialed.

content.description: Sun Dialed is a stout little sport climb.  High value. It is the 4-bolt route located 50 feet to the right of Crack of Dawn, the crack above the the large square blocks.
Short but fun climbing up the right-arching layback seam.  Moves onto ledge at the top of seam are harder than you think.
content.location: On the small formation a hundred yards past the Red Dwarf on the way to Solar Flare.

content.description:
THIS ROUTE NO LONGER EXISTS.  DO NOT CLIMB.

  Another much needed 5.10 at the Sun Spots.  Two  cruxes makes this route interesting.   Climb slab to steep bit with good holds, then left to steeper arete with good holds.
content.location: Climbs left side of formation just right of Red Dwarf formation.

content.description: Sustained, devious, and pumpy.  Doesn't let up till your done.
content.location: On the south face of the Solar Flare formation, just right of the large tree.

content.description: Engaging climbing up the obvious sharp corner, then onto a few fun face moves to the chains.
content.location: On the formation just left of Solar Flare.

content.description: Solar Flare is a very good, albeit short, route on perfect rock that nearly justifies the approach by itself.  Originally a fully bolted sport route, Solar Flare has been revised to be a full on traditional route.  The route was chopped by the FA after reconsidering the placements, recognizing the lack of quality gear routes on the mountain, and a community vote.
content.location: Solar Flare is located on a small cliff about 200 yards to the left (west) of the Sunburst Crag.

content.description: Solar E-clips is located in the middle of the Sunburst Crag and climbs a major weakness. The line starts in a dihedral under a roof.  There are some interesting moves into a open groove.  The top is exceptional with steep pocket (yes, pocket) pulls.  This thing took some clean up, but it is fairly sweet in its current state.  8 or so bolts. Sparky speaks the truth.
Shares chains with Filet of Sol.    Climb slab left to blunt arete.
content.location: First bolt line right of big Chimney on Heliosphere.

content.description: Hard face moves past bolts lead to fun crack climbing to a roof. Pull roof, way fun!!, past 2 bolts to chains.
content.protection: The only piece you can't suss out from the ground is a 0 tcu in a horizontal between the second bolt and the crack proper.
content.location: Obvious slanting crack on a formation above the Griddle on the way to the Heliosphere.

content.description: The opening moves are hard as well as the last steep crack section.  It is a hard crack on Mt. Lemmon and that is cool.  JSt, and Erik Murdock put in the anchors and 1st bolt.  Many have top-roped it from the anchors on English Breakfast Crack.  Last week I cleaned up most of the choss on the route.  I figured out the pro and racked it in order before I lead it.  Onsighting this will take some endurance and quick gear placements.
content.protection: 1 bolt, pro to red camalot.  You can take a big cam for the move to the chains but smaller stuff will work.  Lots of good stoppers to be had from pinky to 3/4 inch.
content.location: Starts on the right side of the Griddle which is the first wall you encounter at Sun Spots.  The start is the same as English Breakfast Crack.  Climb short crack to ledge. That square block that looks funky is quite solid.  Neither route takes the blocky ramp to the ledge.

content.description: Short left angling crack 5.12 leads to a big ledge and total recovery. Move back right and clip one of two bolts (for top-roping crack) then head up steep face 5.11 to anchors.  These double bolts can be reached by climbing around the left side of the formation to the previously mentioned ledge.  You can hang draws on these to TR the crack.  Take some small cams for directionals.  You can also hike to top of crag tie off an oak work out to the front of the formation and single line rap to chains.  You then have to have someone untie the rope so you can set up the TR.  Or you can lead it.
content.protection: Gear to yellow camalot size.  A couple of purple or green cams is helpful.  A great wired stopper can be worked in from the ground with a stick to protect the first moves.
content.location: From the Griddle hike for two minutes up and left along the wall.  Where the trail splits at a cairn go left 50 feet and you will be below the Red Dwarf

content.description: Climb easy rock to ledge, 10 feet left of Sun Demon.     Pull onto arete and crank to top. Gets harder the higher you get.
content.location: Obvious arete on left side of small formation 100 yards past Red Dwarf on the way to Solar Flare.

climbs.name: Northern Tights
climbs.fa: Eric Ruljancich, Geir Hundal, Christian Rodenbeck

content.description:
Fun, fingery, technical climbing up slightly overhanging face.  Several cruxes increasing in difficulty make this a solid little line.

 Note:  The name, a tribute to the play on words of the climb to the right, did certainly involve a Canadian in spandex.
content.location: Ten feet left of Aurora No Boreals

content.description: The crux is moving off the bottom block into the crack.  Right now there are no chains, but these will be added.  Exit right and use the chains to the right.
content.protection: Small and medium cams, with a #5 Camalot for the top, if you want it.
content.location: This is the squeeze chimney on the left flank of the Sunburst wall as you look at it from below.

content.description: Interesting crux.
content.location: This route is on the upper left end of The Griddle.  The route like many here is short but packs a lot of climbing in a short distance.

content.description: This photo shows a climber on Filet of Sol.  Magnetopause is an overhanging blunt arete.  It starts just left of Cragmire.  The top of both of those climbs is left of the climber where a large ledge can be seen on the left skyline.  After a pause to shake out it is tricky but way more fun to move back right and finish the top moves of the arete.
Start the same as Euro-lite but head right around roof.  Hard start then the rest of the route eases off but not too much.
content.location: On the Brown Dwarf which is on the way to the Heliosphere.  The climb starts to the right of the right-angling crack that starts about 15 feet above a bolted hard slab See The Light 5.11.

content.description: Around the corner to the left of Red Dwarf.  The first route you come to is The Wedge 5.10.  The second is Krymptonite.  Start up crack in short left facing dihedral with a hand sized cam or walk around to the top of the pillar and start clipping bolts.
content.protection: bolts and a hand sized cam if you climb the short dihedral.

content.description: Short powerful route with good moves.  If we could have come up with 10 bouldering pads we would have made it a highball.  Just kidding!
content.location: Hike up trail past The Griddle.  At the Cairn look up.  It is the short wall left of the wall with the crack in it.

content.description: Hard start up cracks and seams lead to tricky face.
content.location: On the right end of the Heliosphere this is the route that starts just left of a big crack.

content.description: This route is on The Griddle which is the first formation you reach when hiking up to Sun Spot Crags.  It has three distinct cruxes.  Start on rocks at base of low angle left leaning corner with pale SMC hangers.  After first SMC hanger on the old route Hardboiled 5.9- clip a Fixe bolt on the right face.  Follow left leaning ramps to tricky bulge.  Climb steep face and after clipping a chain draw pull on to  overhanging headwall and head to the anchors.  The two run out sections were not bolted to maintain the integrity of the existing route Hard Boiled 5.9- which stays left of the chimney until you can hand traverse an angling crack into the chimney above  the bulge.
content.protection: Bolts  Finger sized piece gets you to the first fixe hanger of Hashbrowns.  One hand sized cam makes easy chimney safe.

content.description: Start from rocky ledge and climb left-facing dihedral with pale SMC hangers. (New style and safe) Climb past third or fourth bolt before traversing right with good gear to the chimney.  If you traverse at the bolt you will have a harder but well protected bulge to surmount.
content.protection: Light rack up to hand sized cams.

climbs.name: Fun With Dick And Bob
climbs.fa: Robert McLeod, Dick Williams, EFR, EMk,'06

content.description: Boulder up crack or bring a hand sized cam to protect the first 10 feet.
content.protection: Bolts, and a hand sized cam if you don't want to boulder up to the first bolt.
content.location: This route starts in a woter stained crack but stays left of the buttress and wider crack above.

content.description: Steep warm up for the harder routes on Heliosphere.   Climb right to steep face and ledge.  Thin moves left off ledge lead to chains on Sol Survivor.
content.location: Second bolt line to the right of the big Chimney

content.description:
A sport variation to See the Light.  Clip first two bolts on Lean on Me then bust left to roof.    Avoids 5.11 face moves on See the Light and the need for gear. 

  A good warm up climb.
content.location: On formation with obvious slanting crack on formation above The Griddle on the way to the Heliosphere.

content.description: 5.8+/10+ This route has been set up so you can do the 5.8+ crack then lower off from chains or go through the bolted 5.10 upper headwall and lower off. This splitter crack starts on the right side of the formation now being called The Griddle. It is around the corner and can't be seen when looking at the wall itself. A short slightly grungy section leads to a ledge. A few dihedral moves get you to about 25 feet of great finger crack. If you climb past the first chains you will be on the 5.10 upper headwall.
content.protection: Mostly finger sized stoppers and cams although a big cam will give you some peace of mind getting to the first ledge.

content.description: Dihedral, to crack, to wide but not unpleasant crack to classic Mt lemmon face climbing across the headwall to the final crux moves. This route is on the upper tier of rocks called the Heliosphere.  Follow trail at the base of the first wall you reach (The Griddle) up and left to a cairn.  Contour east or right following more cairns. Where you start going up the hill turn back west gradually gaining altitude until you reach the left side of another couple of crags. (200 ft.)  Head up the gully to base of cliff.  Walk left under an oak tree.  This slightly overhanging  route starts in the short orange dihedral with a bolt.

In your face crack with one bolt. Traverse in from left on top of scary, but solid, blocks or climb straight over them.   If you cut left at top of first crack instead of right to the bolt, the route is 5.10.    Both variations have chains at top.
content.protection: Standard rack of cams and stoppers.
content.location: Obvious crack line(s) 30 feet left of Sun Dialed.    Look for one bolt half way up route.

content.description: Approach the same as Filet of Sol.  Moderate trad climbing with good pro to a short safe crux section.

Hard start traverses into seam and crack  Stick clip the first bolt or have good spotters.  To reach this route and Angus Kong 10- Start at The Griddle and hike left and up about 150 feet to cairn.  The route is on the short cliff about 40 feet right above you.
This rout starts by climbing a crack that it is best  not to get into.  From ledge climb up buttress.
content.location: This route is up at the Heliosphere which is a wall that is divided by a saddle.  It is on the east wall which is to the right of where the trail ends.

content.description: This route left us uninspired for two months due to it's short length and the other routes we were looking at doing.  It turns out to be really fun climbing on overhanging rock with good holds.  A perfect warm-up for harder routes if done a few times in a row.
content.location: Upper left end of The Griddle.  Follows cracks and seams to a bit of wide crack.  Don't let the wide crack deter you as you don't get into it.

content.description: Calling this a chimney does it no justice.  It is more of a crack corner system with good pro.  You only do about 5 feet chimneying on the entire climb.  From the top of the chockstone climb straight up to crack in headwall (5.9-) or move right and up then back left to crack(5.7).
content.protection: Standard rack to 3 inch cam size.
content.location: The obvious chimney you see when you reach the Heliosphere.

content.description: Two distinct well protected cruxes.
content.location: The right side of the Heliosphere.  Climbs the seams up the middle of the cliff.

content.description: Approach by taking trail left from the first wall encountered (The Griddle).  At the first cairn you can see the route just 40 feet above you.  It is a short crack corner leading to a slight bulge with a bolt. It is left of a reddish buttress with a bolted crack seam (Brighter Side Of Darkness 12-)to the right.

climbs.name: Ain't no Sunshine When it's Gone

content.description: Intriguing face climbing on small but good edges, with a balancy crux and a big pull over the final bulge.
content.location: On the formation 20 feet left of Solar Flare.  Just left of Solar sys-stem

content.description: This route was done in the interest of having more moderate routes and because there are some fun cracks at the end of it that can't be reached if you don't climb 5.11.  This route is on The Griddle and involves a lot of traversing to the left.  Start at the base of the big left leaning dihedral.  Clip the first three Fixe bolts of Sunny Side Up .  Use a long runner at the 3rd bolt (unpainted). Now head left to another unpainted bolt.   A tricky move gets you to a crack that can be climbed to the top or keep on moving left to the cracks.  Continue up these to chains then belay your partner.  Rap off.  If you want to practice multi pitch there is a great crack where you could set up a belay 15 feet past the 4th bolt.  This also alleviates rope drag especially if you go straight up from there.
content.location: Starts the same as Sunny Side Up on the Griddle

content.description: The Sun Spot Crags are a sunny, winter climbing area that's visible from the Molino Campground as a low, south-facing cliff band.  There are more than 20 routes to do from 5.7 to 5.12. There was only one route, bolted by Strassman, on the crag until December 2005. Some of the other lines, including chimneys, have been climbed/toproped in the past. Rock quality is variable although all the routes are surprisingly good. Solar Flare, the farthest route to the west, is on great rock and is top notch by Lemmon standards. Bring a standard rack for a few excellent cracks and mixed routes. Routes were cleaned although there may be some residual crustiness on a few. If you are looking for a low, sunny crag with warm temps, this place is a worthwhile alternative to the Ruins or Club Med.
